posts.title: Javascript
posts.content:
JavaScript is a versatile scripting language used to create dynamic and interactive web content.
It runs in the browser and powers features like animations, form validation, and API calls.
Modern frameworks like React and Vue make building complex UIs easier with JavaScript.

posts.title: Golang
posts.content:
An open-source programming language supported by Google
Easy to learn and great for teams
Built-in concurrency and a robust standard library
Large ecosystem of partners, communities, and tools

posts.title: Tailwind
posts.content: Tailwind CSS is an open-source CSS framework. Unlike other frameworks, like Bootstrap, it does not provide a series of predefined classes for elements such as buttons or tables. Instead, it creates a list of "utility" CSS classes that can be used to style each element by mixing and matching

posts.title: CSS Grid vs Flexbox
posts.content: Grid is best for 2D layouts, while Flexbox excels in 1D layouts

posts.title: Async/Await in TypeScript
posts.content: Async/await syntax makes asynchronous code easier to read and maintain

posts.title: Top 5 VS Code Extensions
posts.content: Extensions like Prettier, ESLint, and GitLens boost productivity.

posts.title: REST vs GraphQ
posts.content: GraphQL allows clients to request exactly what they need, unlike REST

posts.title: Understanding Redux Toolkit
posts.content: Redux Toolkit simplifies Redux setup with less boilerplate

posts.title: Debounce vs Throttle
posts.content: Debounce delays execution, throttle limits execution rate

posts.title: Building a Todo App with React
posts.content: A simple project to learn React fundamentals like state and props

posts.title: Dark Mode in CSS
posts.content: Use prefers-color-scheme media query to support dark mode

posts.title: MUI
posts.content: MUI offers a comprehensive suite of free UI tools to help you ship new features faster. Start with Material UI, our fully-loaded component library, or bring your own design system to our production-ready components.
